1.heading: Greens.
1.title: "Dr. Blog Recommended More Greens For Me"
1.author: Hoest & Reiner.
notes: Summary: Leroy is leaving to play golf.

2.heading: Greens.
2.title: "Eat All Your Greens. It's St. Patrick's Day"
2.author: Bil Keane.

3.heading: Greens.
3.title: "I Have a Kindly Neighbor Who Sees That I Eat My Greens"
3.author: Saunders and Giella.
notes: Summary: Mary gives Mr. Ford a salad and some fruit for lunch.

4.heading: Greens.
4.title: "You're Not Eating Your Greens"
4.author: Bittle.
notes: Summary: It's the meat.

5.heading: Greens.
5.title: "Be Careful of the Water Hazard"
5.author: by Bill Rechin and Don Wilder
5.appears_in: dated 1989 and reproduced on p. 150 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The hazard is a canteen being emptied in the desert between the tee and the green.

6.heading: Greens.
6.title: "By George, Thornapple, I'm Finally Getting the Hang of It!"
6.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: On the green, Veeblefester is playing with a paddleball while Brutus's putt bounces back up out of the hole.

7.heading: Greens.
7.title: "Dr. Blog Recommended More Greens For Me"
7.author: Hoest & Reiner.
notes: Summary: Leroy is leaving to play golf.

8.heading: Greens.
8.title: "The Doctor Said We're Not Getting Enough Greens"
8.author: by Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: Two monsters are eating greens, each complete with a hole, a pin, and a golfer.

9.heading: Greens.
9.title: "The First Green is In Sight!"
9.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: The turtle has been on the golf course for four hours.

10.heading: Greens.
10.title: "Get Legs!"
10.author: by Charles Schulz.
notes: Summary: Charlie Brown is talking to the ball that Snoopy has just hit onto the green.

11.heading: Greens.
11.title: "He's Still Away, Folks"
11.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: It's 200 yards to the green for Grog, but his drive overshoots by a similar distance.

12.heading: Greens.
12.title: "How Much If You Didn't Use the Green?"
12.author: Thaves.
notes: Summary: Frank is trying to get a discount on the green fee.

13.heading: Greens.
13.title: "I Couldn't Possibly Reach the Green with Just a 5-Iron"
13.author: Cullum & Marshall.

14.heading: Greens.
14.title: "I Hate These Greens"
14.author: Hart.
notes: The ground falls away from the edges of the green like a mesa.

15.heading: Greens.
15.title: "I Need a Starting Time for Tomorrow, Harry"
15.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: Brutus says golf is crummy, miserable and frustrating, and hates tees, roughs, fairways, and greens.

16.heading: Greens.
16.title: "I Was Wondering How You'd Play That Shot"
16.author: by Jim Unger
16.appears_in: reproduced on p. 162 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The golf ball is shooting up out of the green.

17.heading: Greens.
17.title: "If Your Handicap is Above 15 Putt for This Hole"
17.author: by John McPherson.
notes: Summary: The green has two holes, of very different sizes.

18.heading: Greens.
18.title: "I'm Utterly Way Off My Game Today"
18.author: by Harry Haenigsen.
notes: Summary: Penny's on the green, but she usually lands in the sand trap.

19.heading: Greens.
19.title: "Indoor Putting Green"
19.author: by Carl Anderson
19.appears_in: reproduced on p. 110 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Henry uses a bearskin rug for indoor golf.

20.heading: Greens.
20.title: "It says 'Four-Putt'"
20.author: MacNelly.
notes: Summary: Shoe can read the green just fine.

21.heading: Greens.
21.title: "Nobody's Three-Putted This Green Yet, Tank"
21.author: Millar ; Hinds.
notes: Summary: Difficult golf courses are for identifying, not humiliating, great golfers.

22.heading: Greens.
22.title: "Odd Ball"
22.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Lord P. is teed off, lost his third ball, and to his surprise the sneaky thing is right by the green.

23.heading: Greens.
23.title: "A Plugger Putting on the Green"
23.author: Brookins.
notes: Summary: Mowing the lawn with a riding lawnmower (putt-putt).

24.heading: Greens.
24.title: "The Robert Frost Caddy School"
24.author: Hart
24.appears_in: reproduced on p. 131 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The caddy reads the green, saying, 'The blades are lovely, green and slick, Just perfect for your putting stick'.

25.heading: Greens.
25.title: "So There I Was, On the Green in Two"

notes: Summary: She's heard the story before and cuts it off with a tape recording.

26.heading: Greens.
26.title: "This Looks Like an Easy Pitch to the Green"
26.author: MacNelly.
notes: Copyright line says 1996, but this was clipped from a 1998 newspaper.
Summary: First Cosmo checks to see that nobody's looking, then he throws his ball.

27.heading: Greens.
27.title: "A Three-Wood, a Four-Iron, and a Rake!"
27.author: Schulz.
notes: Summary: Charlie Brown wonders what it'll take to get out of the trap and onto the green.

28.heading: Greens.
28.title: "Wait, Avery Wants to Putt"
28.author: King.

29.heading: Greens.

29.appears_in: reproduced on p. 78-79 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Jack is tricked into landing on a golf course, and the manager of the club is going to report him to the authorities.

30.heading: Greens.
30.title: "You Don't Know What You're Doing, but at Least You Look Good"
30.author: Wise-Aldrich.
notes: Summary: He's dangling his putter over his ball on the green.

31.heading: Greens.
31.title: "You Get a Second Chance Coming Back"
31.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: The golfers are at the bottom edge of a steeply angled green.

32.heading: Greens.
32.title: "You Overlook the Ninth Green on the Golf Course!"

notes: Summary: A realtor is showing a house as a ball comes through the window.

33.heading: Greens Fees.
33.title: "Divide the Greens Fee by your Total Strokes"

notes: Summary: Thirsty has a way to make golf seem like a bargain.

35.heading: Greens Fees.

notes: Summary: He has the faculty golf club ready to go, but hasn't done anything about their wedding.

36.heading: Greens Fees.
36.title: "It Takes Me 17 Holes to Get Over Paying a Week's Salary for the Greens Fee and a Cart"
36.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: He only ever plays well on the 18th hole.

37.heading: Greens Fees.
37.title: "You Have to Pay For Those Pleasures"

notes: Summary: Sal got mosquito bitten and sunburned in her garden, and says its no worse than playing golf, except there's no greens fee.

58.heading: Greenwood.
58.title: "Rosebug"
58.author: Byron Preiss, Tom Sutton
notes: Summary: The janitor at Radio City Music Hall has been killed by a sandbag, and the word "Rosebug" has been written by the victim in the spilled sand. Schlomo, Orsoni Wells, and the FBI arrive to investigate. The FBI says there's a Negro acting as a German spy in the show, and Wells rewrites the script to trick him into revealing himself during the performance His name is Greenwood, and he gets away. Looking for him, Schlomo finds a nest of German spies and hears that they're heading for Washington. With Wells and the FBI, Schlomo heads for Washington. In Washington they apprehend Greenwood pretending to be an ambassador from England. Schlomo doesn't think the case is over, and indeed soon notices that Orsoni Wells' shoes make a footprint that spells "Rosebug." The Wells in Washington is a fake Wells sent by the Germans to bomb a meeting in the Pentagon. Schlomo disarms the bomb and rescues the real Wells.
Call no: PN6726.F5v.1

120.heading: Greeting Cards.
120.title: "The Valentine Candy"
120.author: [No author]
120.series: Homer Pigeon) 6 p. in New Funnies, no. 97
notes: Summary: Homer loses his $5 on the way to buy candy for Carrie Pigeon. Red Cardinal finds the money, and buys the candy. The druggist hires Homer to deliver the candy to Carrie, and gives Homer a valentine card as payment. Red sabotages the delivery, not knowing the candy is the box he bought, and Carrie is happy with her valentine from Homer and nothing from Red.

128.title: "Happy New Year!"
128.author: Watson Home Stew.
notes: Summary: A snowball on the back of the head is a New Years' greeting.

129.heading: Greetings.
129.title: "High Altitude Cocktail"
129.author: Jim Berry.
notes: Summary: Panel without words, in which a man on a mountain with a flushed nose and stemware greets a St. Bernard with a keg.

130.heading: Greeting.
130.title: "The Hunting Party"
130.author: by P
130.appears_in: Christin ; illustrated by Enki Bilal. p. 37-44 in Heavy Metal, v. 8, no. 5 (Aug. 1984).
notes: "The Silent Vassili Alexandrovitch Tchevtchenko and his two companions have arrived at their destination and are being greeted by the other members of the hunting party."
"To be continued."

131.heading: Greetings.
131.title: "I Hope You're Up for a Challenge!"
131.author: Hank Ketcham.
notes: Summary: Dennis greets a babysitter.

132.heading: Greetings.
132.title: "I Wonder Where She's Going?"
132.author: Young & Drake.
notes: Summary: Daisy comes running apparently to greet Dagwood, but runs right by.

133.heading: Greetings.
133.title: "It's a Pleasure To See You on Such a Grand Morning, Mr. Cronin- Out of Golf Balls?"
133.author: Larry Reynolds
133.appears_in: dated 1942 and reproduced on p. 413 of Cartoon Cavalcade, ed. by Thomas Craven (Chicago : Consolidated Book Publishers, 1945)
notes: Mr. Cronin has come to church and is being greeted by the priest.

134.heading: Greetings.
134.title: "Long Distance Revenge"
134.author: by Bruce Beattie.
notes: Summary: An answering machine greeting is long and involved so that callers will have to pay to leave their messages.

135.heading: Greetings.
135.title: "Male Bonding Just Isn't the Same When It's With Your Dog"
135.author: Mark O'Hare.
notes: Summary: Fergus greets Mel with a punch on the shoulder.

136.heading: Greetings.
136.title: "A Place to Wipe It Off"
136.author: Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: The owner is pleased with the greeting, and the dog is glad too because his tongue has been in disgusting places.

137.heading: Greetings.
137.title: Season's Greetings.
137.author: [No author]
notes: New wave mini comic about Christmas.

138.heading: Greetings.
138.title: "Season's Greetings"
138.author: Moebius
138.appears_in: 2 p. in Moebius 1/2 (Anaheim, CA : Graphitti Designs, 1991).
notes: Summary: A gang member pretends to help an old lady in order to rob her; she turns out to be a good fairy so he kills her and takes her jewelry.
Originally in Hara-Kiri in 1963 or 1964.

139.heading: Greetings.
139.title: "The Subdued Gush"
139.author: Cathy Guisewite.
notes: Summary: Cathy greets Electra effusively, and Cathy's mom says, "ditto" to Cathy.

140.heading: Greetings.
140.title: "When Rachel and Neddy Arrive at the Club, a Handsome Young Gentleman Greets Them!"
140.author: LeDoux and Wilson.
notes: Summary: His name is Willard.

141.heading: Greetings.
141.title: "Whistling Monkey Cowboy Band Land"
141.author: Kirkman & Scott.
notes: Summary: Dad greets proposed day trip with nothing that could be said in mixed company.
Key word: Amusement parks.

142.heading: Greetings.
142.title: "World-Wide Greeting Customs!"
142.author: Tom Nicolisi, script and art
142.appears_in: 1 p. non-fiction in Wonder Woman, no. 77 (Oct. 1955).
notes: Describes the origin of shaking hands.
Data from Gene Reed and Lou Mougin, via Grand Comic-Book Database.
